objtitle.title: *Procession of Monks, Met by Three Women*

objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe work is inscribed on the verso, in a twentieth-century hand, "Sketch by Blake R.A. R.C." and "By Blake."

provenance.name: Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University
provenance.note: Possibly acquired at an unknown time, probably directly from Blake or his wife Catherine, by John Flaxman; possibly his sister-in-law Maria Denham; possibly his niece, Miss Denham; possibly the drawing sold Christie's, 26 Feb. 1883, "Drawings and the Remaining Works of ... John Flaxman," lot 210, "Figures by W. Blake" with a drawing of "a horseman" by Thomas Stothard (£1.13s. to "Money," probably a code name for a dealer, possibly James Tregaskis); Tregaskis, 19 July 1915 Caxton Head Catalogue 770, item 91 (£7.7s.), and 1917 Caxton Head Catalogue 786, item 48 (£7.7s.); Mrs. Arthur H. Brooks; bequeathed by Brooks in 1970 to the Fogg Art Museum.

desc.objtitle:
Procession of Monks, Met by Three Women,
object 1 (Butlin 100)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left toward a group of three standing figures who face right. The closer monk in the two rightmost pairs each holds a rectangular object, perhaps a book, by his left side. The leftmost monk who leads the procession appears to extend a similar object toward the foregrounded figure at left, who extends an arm perhaps to receive it. Like the monks, this figure may wear a gown, though not a hood, and long, perhaps curly, hair is visible, suggesting this figure is female. This figure may hold something in her(?) right hand. The second figure immediately behind and to the right of this figure also extends her(?) left arm. The leftmost figure in the trio appears gowned; she(?) may already holds a similar rectangular object or book by her right side.

component.illusobjdesc: Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left. The leftmost monk who leads the procession extends at least his left arm. He appears to hold a rectangular object, perhaps a book, and be in the act of giving it to a standing figure at left, at whom he may look.

Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left. The closer monk in the two rightmost pairs each holds a rectangular object, perhaps a book, by his left side.

Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left toward a group of three standing figures who face right. The central figure in the trio has long, perhaps curly, hair, suggesting she is female. She may wear a gown and hold something in her lowered right hand. Her left arm is slightly extended and she appears to be receiving or taking the rectangular object or book from the nearest monk, at whom she looks.

Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left toward a group of three standing figures who face right. The rightmost figure in this trio (who is only partially visible behind the central figure) may wear a gown. She(?) extends at least one arm, which echoes the gesture of her companion at left.

Three pairs of figures, who appear to wear monastic robes with hoods and thus are likely monks, stand or walk to the left toward a group of three standing figures who face right. The leftmost figure in this trio may wear a gown and perhaps also a hat(?); alternatively, this figure may have long or styled hair, suggesting she is female. She holds or carries a rectangular objects by her right side that may be a book.

This scene contains four rectangular objects that may represent four books: one by the right side of the leftmost figure; one being given by the leftmost monk to the standing figure across from him; one by the left side of the fourth monk from the right; and one by the left side of the second monk from the left.
